content:
I’m a Fourth Year Undergraduate at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur (IITK), Double Majoring in Mathematics and Electrical Engineering. My research interests lie in the mathematical foundations of Machine Learning, with a focus on Optimization, High Dimensional Statistics, and Approximate Inference. I also maintain an active interest in continuous-time Machine Learning with ODEs and SDEs, and Deep Generative Models.
Since my Sophomore Year, I’ve been working as a Research Assistant in Prof. Piyush Rai’s group at IITK, focusing on Approximate Inference and Deep Generative Models. My previous work under Prof. Rai’s group involved developing Generative Models for Joint Image and Video Generation, and nonparametric priors for GANs using Second-Order ODEs. Currently, I am working on developing an extension of the Model Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML) Algorithm for meta-learning of continuous-time dynamical systems, and investigating results from SDE theory to improve the performance of Stochastic Gradient MCMC Algorithms.
I spent my Third Year as an Exchange Student at Aalto University School of Science, Finland, where I worked as a Research Assistant under Dr. Markus Heinonen and Prof. Harri Lahdesmaki, focusing on Approximate Bayesian Inference and Adversarial Learning for continuous-time generative models governed by ODEs and SDEs.
I’m currently looking for Research Assistantship and collaboration opportunities in Optimization, Approximate Inference, High Dimensional Statistics, and Learning Theory. If you’re interested in a collaboration or have an opening in your research group where I could be of some use, please feel free to contact me.

content:
Supervisor: Prof. Simo Särkkä, Aalto University
As part of the term project for Aalto University’s course on State Space Models, titled Non-linear Filtering and Parameter Estimation, I investigated the continuous-time Bayesian Filtering problem for continuous-time State Space Models governed by Stochastic Differential Equations. I studied the theory of continuous-time Markov Chains, Brownian Motion, Ito Calculus and and the Fokker Planck PDE. I also studied the Kushner-Stratonovic and Zakai Equations for likelihood calculations in SDE models. Finally, I studied and implemented exact and approximate Kalman Filters for Continuous-Discrete State Space Models, which are a special class of SDE based SSMs where the State Transition model is an SDE, and the observation model is discrete-time but may be non-uniform. The project report is available here and the implementations are available in this GitHub repository

content:
Supervisor: Prof. Piyush Rai, IIT Kanpur
We developed a generative model for images that uses Probabilistic Second Order Neural ODEs to learn a distribution of smooth continuous-time interpolation trajectories for a given source-target pair, and generates individual images by temporal subsampling of random interpolation curves that are drawn from the conditional (conditioned on the source-target pair) distribution of trajectories. The resultant model was formulated as a modified Generative Adversarial Network with a non-parametric data dependent latent code prior. We qualitatively and quantitatively demonstrated that our non-parametric approach significantly outperforms baseline GAN and Bidirectional GAN models that impose a fixed prior on the latent code, on both image generation and interpolation. Furthermore, our approach also allowed conditional generation and interpolation on out-of-sample data at test-time, with zero training overhead. This work is currently submitted to the International Conference on Computer Vision (ICCV) 2021, and a preprint shall be made available soon.

summary: We propose a generative model for images that learns a distribution of continuous-time interpolation trajectories for a given source-target pair, and generates images by subsampling random interpolation curves drawn from the trajectory distribution. The conditional distribution of interpolation trajectories is parameterised by Second Order Neural ODEs. We formulate the overall model as a modified Generative Adversarial Network with a nonparametric data-dependent noise prior and observe significant improvements in image generation and interpolation when benchmarked against appropriate GAN and Bidirectional GAN baselines that employ a fixed noise prior. The work is currently under review at the International Conference on Computer Vision (ICCV), 2021. The arXiv preprint and code shall be released shortly.
title: NeurInt : Learning to Interpolate through Neural ODEs

summary: We develop a hierarchical probabilistic model for joint image and video generation that generates a summary frame for the video, and models individual frames by adding residual vectors to the summary frame representation at each timestep.  We also develop an analogous hierarchy for models that disentangle content from motion by adding a residual content vector to the content summary representation at every timestep.
title: Joint Image and Video Generation using Residual Vectors

summary: TorchGAN is a PyTorch based framework for writing succinct and comprehensible code for training and evaluation of Generative Adversarial Networks. The framework's modular design allows effortless customization of the model architecture, loss functions, training paradigms, and evaluation metrics and its features bear almost zero overhead over vanilla PyTorch. Currently submitted to *Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS)*. An arXiv preprint is available [here](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1909.03410.pdf)
title: TorchGAN: A Flexible Framework for GAN Training and Evaluation

content:
Supervisors: Prof. Piyush Rai and Prof. Vinay Namboodiri, IIT Kanpur
We developed a hierarchical probabilistic model for joint image and video generation that first generates a summary frame for the video and then models individual frames by adding residual vectors to the summary frame’s latent representation at each timestep. We then developed an analogous hierarchy for models that disentangle content from motion by adding a residual content vector to the content summary representation at each timestep. We designed both VAE and GAN implementations of our proposed models and achieved significant improvements on quantitative metrics and human evaluation scores against appropriate image generation and video generation baseline. Our work is published at the Winter Conference on the Applications of Computer Vision 2020

content: I co-developed TorchGAN, a lightweight customizable PyTorch framework for training and evaluation of Generative Adversarial Networks. This enjoyable passion project involved me embarking on a thorough survey of the GAN literature and writing efficient implementations of various GAN models, losses, evaluation metrics and stability enhancement features, all packaged into a highly customizable framework for effortlessly using them off-the-shelf or extending them. The GitHub Repository currently has over 1200 stars and a paper is currently submitted to the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS)

content:
Supervisor: Prof. Nisheeth Srivastava, IIT Kanpur
The aim of the project was to characterize the nature and granularity of information about social interactions accessible to human observers from simple visual displays. To this end, we studied lay theories of human emotion modelling and developed a computational model for social situations involving few agents, based on the Valence Arousal Model of emotion detection and the Social Force Model for Pedestrian Dynamics

content: I developed a legal consultant bot that summarises a legal document, highlights the key phrases and answers some rudimentary questions about the document as part of the Microsoft code.fun.do Hackathon on AI and NLP. The task involved creating a custom dataset by scrapinng from an archive of Indian legal documents, and using the TextRank Algorithm and Latent Dirichlet Allocation on the large text corpora for topic modelling and extractive summarization. The project was selected as one of the top 3 ideas on campus by Microsoft India.
